speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I are strongly committed to bringing inflation back down, and we’re moving expeditiously to do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have both the tools we need and the resolve it will take to restore price stability on behalf of American families and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economy and the country have been through a lot over the past two and a half years and have proved resilient.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is essential that we bring inflation down to our 2 percent goal if we are to have a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: From the standpoint of our congressional mandate to promote maximum employment and price stability, the current picture is plain to see: The labor market is extremely tight, and inflation is much too high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Against this backdrop, today the FOMC raised its policy interest rate by ¾ of a percentage point and anticipates that ongoing increases in the target range for the federal funds rate will be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, we are continuing the process of significantly reducing the size of our balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’ll have more to say about today’s monetary policy actions after briefly reviewing economic developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Recent indicators of spending and production have softened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Growth in consumer spending has slowed significantly, in part reflecting lower real disposable income and tighter financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Activity in the housing sector has weakened, in part reflecting higher mortgage rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And after a strong increase in the first quarter, business fixed investment also looks to have declined in the second quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Despite these developments, the labor market has remained extremely tight, with the unemployment rate near a 50-year low, job vacancies near historical highs, and wage growth elevated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the past three months, employment rose by an average of 375,000 jobs per July 27, 2022 month—down from the average pace seen earlier in the year, but still robust.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Improvements in Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL labor market conditions have been widespread, including for workers at the lower end of the wage distribution as well as for African Americans and Hispanics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Labor demand is very strong, while labor supply remains subdued, with the labor force participation rate little changed since January.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall, the continued strength of the labor market suggests that underlying aggregate demand remains solid.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation remains well above our longer-run goal of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the 12 months ending in May, total PCE prices rose 6.3 percent; excluding the volatile food and energy categories, core PCE prices rose 4.7 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In June, the 12-month change in the consumer price index came in above expectations at 9.1 percent, and the change in the core CPI was 5.9 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Notwithstanding the recent slowdown in overall economic activity, aggregate demand appears to remain strong, supply constraints have been larger and longer lasting than anticipated, and price pressures are evident across a broad range of goods and services.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Although prices for some commodities have turned down recently, the earlier surge in prices of crude oil and other commodities that resulted from Russia’s war on Ukraine has boosted prices for gasoline and food, creating additional upward pressure on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s monetary policy actions are guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I are acutely aware that high inflation imposes significant hardship, especially on those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are highly attentive to the risks high inflation poses to both sides of our mandate, and we are strongly committed to returning inflation to our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At today’s meeting, the Committee raised the target range for the federal funds rate by ¾ of a percentage point, bringing the target range to 2¼ to 2½ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re continuing the process of significantly reducing the size of our balance sheet, which plays an important role in firming the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over coming months, we will be looking for compelling evidence that inflation is moving down, consistent with inflation returning to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We anticipate that ongoing increases in the target range for the federal funds rate will be appropriate; the pace of those increases will continue to depend on the incoming data and the evolving outlook for the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today’s increase is the—in the target range is the second 75 basis point increase in as many meetings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While another unusually large increase could be appropriate at our next meeting, that is a decision that will depend on the data we get between now and then.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will continue to make our decisions meeting by meeting and communicating—and communicate our thinking as clearly as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the stance of monetary policy tightens further, it likely will become appropriate to slow the pace of increases while we assess how our cumulative policy adjustments are affecting the economy and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our overarching focus is using our tools to bring demand into better balance with supply in order to bring inflation back down to our 2 percent goal and to keep longer-term inflation expectations well anchored.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Making appropriate monetary policy in this uncertain environment requires a recognition that the economy often involves—evolves in unexpected ways.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation has obviously surprised to the upside over the past year, and further surprises could be in store.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We therefore will need to be nimble in responding to incoming data and the evolving outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we will strive to avoid adding uncertainty in what is already an extraordinarily challenging and uncertain time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are highly attentive to inflation risks and determined to take the measures necessary to return July 27, 2022 inflation to our 2 percent longer-run goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This process is likely to involve a period of below- Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL trend economic growth and some softening in labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But such outcomes are likely necessary to restore price stability and to set the stage for achieving maximum employment and stable prices over the longer run.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude: We understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We at the Fed will do everything we can to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I look forward to your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we did judge that a 75 basis point increase was the right magnitude in light of the data and in the context of the ongoing increases in the policy rate that we’ve been making.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’d say that we wouldn’t hesitate to, to make an even larger move than we did today if the Committee were to conclude that that was—that that were appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That was not the case at this meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There was very broad support for the move that we made.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You mentioned the—the June meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we had said many times that we were prepared to move aggressively, more aggressively, if inflation continued to disappoint.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s why we did move to a more aggressive pace at the June meeting, as we said we would do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: July 27, 2022 At this meeting, we continued at that more aggressive pace, as inflation has continued to Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL disappoint, in the form of the June CPI reading.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess I’d start by saying we’ve been saying we would move expeditiously to get to the range of neutral.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think we’ve done that now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re at—we’re at 2.25 to 2.5 [percent], and that’s right in the range of what we think is neutral.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So one thing that hasn’t changed is that—won’t change—is that our focus is continuing to—is going to continue to be on using our tools to bring demand back into better balance with supply in order to bring inflation back down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’ll continue to be our overarching focus.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also said that we expect ongoing rate hikes will be appropriate and that we’ll make decisions meeting by meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’ll be looking at the incoming data, as I mentioned, and that’ll start with economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there’s some evidence that we are at this time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we’ll be looking at labor market July 27, 2022 conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll be asking whether we see the alignment between supply and demand Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL getting better, getting closer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we’ll be looking closely at inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You mentioned headline and core.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our mandate is for headline, of course; it’s not for core.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we look at core because core is, is actually a better indicator of headline and of all inflation going forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ll be—we’ll be looking at both.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll be looking at them for—at those both, really—for what they’re saying about the outlook rather than just simply for, for what they say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in light of all that data, the question we’ll be asking is whether the stance of policy we have is sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation back down to our 2 percent target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s also worth noting that these rate hikes have been large, and they’ve come—they’ve come quickly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s likely that their full effect has not been felt by the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s probably some additional tightening, significant additional tightening, in the pipeline.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the best—I think the Committee broadly feels that we need to get policy to at least to a moderately restrictive level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And maybe the best data point for that would be what we wrote down in our SEP at the—at the June meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think the median [federal funds rate] for the end of this year, the median would’ve been between 3¼ and 3½ [percent].

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, then, people wrote down 50 basis points higher than that for 2023.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s—even though that’s now six weeks old, I guess, that’s—that’s the most recent reading.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we’ll update that reading at the—at the September meeting in eight weeks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how we’re thinking about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, as it relates to September, I said that another unusually large increase could be appropriate, but that’s not a decision we’re making now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s one that we’ll make based July 27, 2022 on the data we see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re going to be making decisions meeting by meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL it’s—we think it’s time to just go to a meeting-by-meeting basis and not provide, you know, the kind of clear guidance that we had provided on the way to neutral.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’m going to start by pointing out that it’s very hard to say with any confidence in normal times—in normal times—what the economy’s going to be doing in 6 or 12 months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And to try to predict what the appropriate monetary policy would respond—response would be—of course, we do that in the SEP, but, nonetheless, you’ve got to take any estimates of what rates will be next year with a grain of salt, because there’s so much uncertainty.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These are not normal times.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s significantly more uncertainty now about the path ahead than I think there ordinarily is, and, ordinarily, it’s quite high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, again, I would—the best data, the only data point I have for you really is the June SEP, which I think is just the most recent thing that the Committee’s done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since then, inflation has come in higher; economic activity has come in weaker than expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But at the same time, I would say that’s probably the best estimate of where the Committee’s thinking is still, which is that we would get to a moderately restrictive level by the end of this year—by which I mean somewhere between 3 and 3½ percent—and that when the Committee sees further rate increases in 2023, as I mentioned, we’ll update that, of course, at the September meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s really the best I can do on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I wouldn’t say it was—I think we didn’t expect a good reading, but this one—this one was even worse than expected, I would say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t talk about my own personal estimate of, of what the terminal rate would be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do—I will write down that in—it’s going to evolve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Obviously, it has evolved over the course—I think, for all participants, it has evolved over the course of the year as we learn how persistent inflation’s going to be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And by the time of the September meeting, we will have seen two more CPI readings and two more labor market readings and a significant amount of readings about economic activity and perhaps geopolitical developments, who knows.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’ll be—it’ll be a lot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s an eight-week intermeeting period, so I think we’ll see quite a lot of data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll make our decision at that meeting based on that data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s hard to deal with hypotheticals, but I just would say this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s really the question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll be making—you know, our policy stance will be set at a level, ultimately, at which we are confident that inflation is going to be moving down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you would—it would depend on a lot of things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, as I mentioned, core inflation is a better predictor of inflation going forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Headline inflation tends to be volatile.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in ordinary times, you, you look through volatile moves in commodities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The problem with the current situation is that, that if you have a sustained period of supply shocks, those can actually start to undermine or to work—to work on de-anchoring inflation expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The public doesn’t distinguish between core and headline inflation in their thinking.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s something we have to take into consideration in our policymaking even though our tools don’t really work on, on some aspects of this, which are the supply-side issues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I—as I mentioned, we think it’s necessary to have growth slow down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And growth is going to be slowing down this year for a couple of reasons, one of which is that you’re coming off of the very high growth of the reopening year of 2021.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re also seeing tighter monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you should see some slowing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We actually think we need a period of growth below potential in order to create some slack so that—so that the supply side can catch up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also think that there will be, in all likelihood, some softening in labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And those are things that we expect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think that they’re probably necessary if we were to have—to get inflation—if we were to be able to get inflation back down on a path to 2 percent and ultimately get there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re going to be—again, we’re going to be focused on getting inflation back down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we—as I’ve said on other occasions, price stability is really the bedrock of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And nothing works in the economy without price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can’t have a strong labor market without price stability for an extended period of time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We all want to get back to the kind of labor market we had before the pandemic, where differences between, you know, racial and gender differences and that kind of thing were at historic minimums, where participation was high, where inflation was low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want to get back to that, but that’s not happening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s not going to happen without, without restoring price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s something we see as, as something that we simply must do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think that in the—we don’t see it as a tradeoff with, with the employment mandate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see it as a way to facilitate the sustained achievement of the employment mandate in the longer term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not—we’re not trying to have a recession.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we don’t think we have to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think that there’s a path for us to be able to bring inflation down while sustaining a strong labor market, as I mentioned, along with—in all likelihood—some, some softening in labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that is—that’s what we’re trying to achieve, and we continue to think that there’s a path to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know that the path has, has clearly narrowed, really based on events that are outside of our control.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it may narrow further.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, I do think—as I said just now—that restoring price stability is just something that we have to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There, there isn’t an option to fail to do that because that is the thing that enables you to have a strong labor market over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Without restoring price stability, you won’t be able, over the medium and longer term, to actually have a strong—a sustained period of very strong labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, of course, we serve both sides of the dual mandate, but we actually see them as well aligned on this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re trying not to make a mistake.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let me put it this way: We do see that there are two-sided risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There would be the risk of doing too much and, you know, imposing more of a downturn on the economy than, than was necessary, but the risk—the risk of doing too little and leaving the economy with this entrenched inflation, it only raises the cost.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If July 27, 2022 you fail to deal with it in the near term, it only raises the cost of, of dealing with it later to the Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL extent people start to see it as just part of their economic lives.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They start to factor high inflation into their decisions—when that—on a sustained basis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When that starts to really happen, and we don’t think that’s happened yet, but when that starts to happen, it just gets that much harder.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the pain will be that much greater.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I really do think that it’s important that we—that we address this now and get it done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t—I do not think the U.S. is currently in a recession.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the reason is, there are just too many areas of the economy that are—that are performing, you know, too well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, of course, I would point to the labor market, in particular.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, it’s true that growth is slowing for reasons that we understand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Really, the growth was extraordinarily high last year, 5½ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We would have expected growth to slow.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s also more slowing going on now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But if you look at the labor market, you’ve got growth—I think, payroll jobs averaging 450,000 per month.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a remarkably strong level for, for this state of, of affairs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate at near a 50-year low at 3.6 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All of the wage measures that we track are running very strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this is a very strong labor market, and it’s just not consistent with—you know, 2.7 million people hired in the first half of the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It doesn’t make sense that the July 27, 2022 economy would be in recession with, with this kind of thing happening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t think the U.S.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL economy’s in recession right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Ah, haven’t seen it, and, and we’ll just have to see what it says.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t—I mean, I would say, generally, the GDP numbers do have a tendency to be revised pretty significantly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just—it’s just that it’s very hard—it’s very hard to cumulate [to an estimate of] U.S. GDP.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a large economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And a lot of—a lot of work and judgment goes into that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you tend to take first GDP reports, I think, with a—with a grain of salt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, of course, it’s something we’ll be looking at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So those are—those are the toughest rules in place, you know, at any comparable institution that I’m aware of.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think—you know, we’ve thought about this carefully, and we put them in place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re building the infrastructure so that—so that, you know, the enforcement will be tight, that, actually, you won’t be able to make trades unless they’re precleared.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just—I think we’ve really, you know, created a very strong and robust set of rules that will, you know, support public trust in the institution.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, we’re just now—the system is just now up and running.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’m proud of what we did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’m going to—I’m going to take that as a question about the next meeting and thereafter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I mentioned, we’re going to be looking at all of those things: activity, labor market, inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re going to be thinking about our policy stance and where does it really need to be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I also mentioned that, as this process—now that we’re at neutral—as the process goes on, at some point, it will be appropriate to, to slow down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve been front-end-loading these very large rate increases, and now we’re getting closer to where we need to be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how we’re thinking about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And in terms of September, we’re going—we’re going to watch the data and the evolving outlook very carefully and factor in everything and make a decision in September about what to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’m not really going to provide any specific guidance about what that might be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, but I mentioned that we might do another unusually large rate increase.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s not a decision that we’ve made at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we are—you know, we’re going to be guided by the data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think you can still think of the, the destination as broadly in line with the September—sorry, the June SEP, because July 27, 2022 it’s only six weeks old.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And sometimes, sometimes SEPs can get old really quick.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think in this Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL one—this one I would say is probably, probably the best guide we have as to where the Committee thinks it needs to get at the end of the year and then into next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would point you to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s an interesting, interesting situation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we’ve, we’ve long used PCE because we think it’s just better at capturing the inflation that people actually face in their lives.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think that that view is pretty widely understood.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That said, the public really reads about CPI.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the difference really is because the CPI has higher weights on things like food, gasoline, motor vehicles, and housing than the PCE index does.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so that accounts for a lot of the difference.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: However, over time, they tend to come together.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we—given the importance in the public eye of CPI, we are calling it out and noticing it and everything like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But remember, we do target PCE.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is because we think it’s a better measure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They will come together eventually.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
